subject: Politics
title: Polling and Predictions
description: A 60-second lesson on Polling and Predictions.

hook.text: Polls said Clinton would win in 2016. She lost. Did polling break â€” or did we just read the data wrong?

buildup.text: Polls sample a small group to estimate how millions will vote. Done right, they're remarkably accurate.

discovery.text: Margins of error matter. A 3-point lead within a 4-point margin means the race is actually a toss-up.

twist.text: Polls can influence behavior. If your candidate looks like a sure winner, you might not bother voting.

climax.text: Pollsters now struggle with response rates. Fewer people answer phones, skewing samples unpredictably.

punchline.text: Polls measure a snapshot, not a prediction. They're clues, not crystal balls.

quiz.question: What does a margin of error in polls mean?
options: The range within which the true result likely falls
The percentage of voters who refused to answer
The number of people who changed their minds
